node.text:
What makes a successful scientist?

2020 Medicine Laureate Charles Rice shares his thoughts on what success means for a scientist.

Watch the full session at YouTube: https://youtu.be/ujQTD3wzzJs

#NobelPrize

node.text:
How much do you know about the trailblazing scientist Barbara McClintock? 

McClintock's pioneering research was long rejected by the scientific community but she didn't give up. Watch our video to learn more about this remarkable laureate. 

#NobelPrize

node.text:
Watch the very moment Ahmed Zewail received his Nobel Prize on 10 December 1999.

Sewail was awarded the chemistry prize "for his studies of the transition states of chemical reactions using femtosecond spectroscopy."

#NobelPrize

node.text:
"Understanding how to deal with things that are messy is so fundamental to research."

Physics Laureate Andrea Ghez on how the path to discovery is often tough and messy.

node.title: Andrea Ghez on the path to discovery

node.text:
Watch the very moment Rita Levi-Montalcini received her Nobel Prize in 1986.

Levi-Montalcini shared the 1986 Medicine Prize with Stanley Cohen "for their discoveries of growth factors."

#NobelPrize

node.text:
"I guess I'd have to start with Buddy Holly"

Listen to a part of Bob Dylan's Nobel Lecture, recorded on 4 June 2017. Dylan was awarded the 2016 Nobel Prize in Literature.

Photo: William Claxton. 

#NobelPrize #NobelLaureate #literature

node.text:
Marie Sklodowska Curie discovered polonium in an experiment conducted in 1898.

Watch the story behind the discovery of polonium, as well as radium, which was also discovered the same year.

#NobelPrize

node.title: Marie Sklodowska Curie and the discovery of polonium

node.text:
Watch the very moment Chemistry Laureate Dorothy Crowfoot Hodgkin receives her Nobel Prize on 10 December 1964.

Crowfoot Hodgkin was the third woman to be awarded the Nobel Prize in Chemistry, following in the footsteps of Marie Curie and her daughter Irène Joliot-Curie.

#nobelprize #nobellaureate

node.title: Dorothy Crowfoot Hodgkin receives her Nobel Prize

node.text:
"My lab has been so well-tuned it feels like a really good band."

Not only is 2018 Medicine Laureate James Allison an award-winning scientist, but he's also an accomplished musician, being part of a national band, the Checkpoints, and a local band, the Checkmates. Here, he shares the similarities between scientific research and playing music.

node.title: Medicine laureate James Allison on music

node.text:
”We have been blinded by greed and power. It is time to strive for peace, and it is time to define peace. Peace is the ability to feel joy while breathing clean air and drinking clean water. Peace requires courage, commitment and determination."

19-year-old climate justice activist Xiye Bastida, @xiyebeara, spoke about our future world at the Nobel Prize Summit earlier this week. 

#NobelPrizeSummit

node.title: Xiye Bastida at the Nobel Prize Summit

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Nobel Prize on July 20, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says '"Peace without freedom is a mockery." ALBERT LUTULI Nobe Peace Prize 1960'.

node.text:
"Peace is indissolubly interwoven with the question of freedom, for peace without freedom is a mockery."

Albert Lutuli - known by his Zulu name as Mvumbi, meaning continuous rain - was Africa's first Nobel Peace Prize laureate. The South African teacher, activist and politician was the leader of ten million black Africans in their nonviolent campaign for civil rights in South Africa. 

A man of noble bearing, charitable, intolerant of hatred, and adamant in his demands for equality and peace among all men, Lutuli forged a philosophical compatibility between two cultures – the Zulu culture of his native Africa and the Christian-democratic culture of Europe.

Lutuli was awarded the 1960 Nobel Peace Prize for his non-violent struggle against apartheid. 

#NobelPrize #NobelLaureate #NobelPeacePrize #peace

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Nobel Prize on July 19, 2021. May be a black-and-white image of 1 person.

node.text:
"The excitement of learning separates youth from old age. As long as you're learning, you're not old."

Take a look at some snapshots of the pioneering physicist Rosalyn Yalow throughout her life. Born on this day 100 years ago, she was awarded the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine 1977 "for the development of radioimmunoassays of peptide hormones." With the help of radioimmunoassay, she proved that type 2 diabetes is caused by the body's inefficient use, rather than lack, of insulin.

Photos: Portrait of Rosalyn Yalow, Yalow on her wedding day in June 1943, Yalow (left) in the lab, Yalow receives her Nobel Prize in 1977.

All photos courtesy of Benjamin Yalow.

node.text:
“I have fought against white domination, and I have fought against black domination. I have cherished the ideal of a democratic and free society in which all persons live together in harmony and with equal opportunities. It is an ideal which I hope to live for and to achieve. But if needs be, it is an ideal for which I am prepared to die.”

Nelson Mandela never gave up on his dream of human rights for all. He dedicated his life to putting an end to apartheid in South Africa and to creating a more democratic society where all human beings are equal.

Mandela founded South Africa’s first black law firm. He became a human rights activist and joined African National Congress, a group fighting for the civil rights of black South Africans. Mandela and his fellow ANC members protested against the apartheid regime.

On 5 August 1962 Mandela was arrested and initially sentenced to five years in prison. He would remain imprisoned for more than 27 years. By the time he was finally released in 1990 he had become one of the most famous international political prisoners in the world, and had won the respect of both his captors and fellow prisoners.

Despite his long imprisonment, Mandela never succumbed to bitterness or feelings of revenge. In 1994, he became South Africa's first black president in the country’s first free elections - in which citizens of all races could take part. 'Madiba', as he was affectionately known, is among the great heroes of history.

Nelson Mandela was awarded the 1993 Nobel Peace Prize. He shared the prize with South African president Frederik Willem de Klerk "for their work for the peaceful termination of the apartheid regime, and for laying the foundations for a new democratic South Africa."

Photo: Louise Gubb/Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Nobel Prize on July 17, 2021 tagging @drdenismukwege. May be an image of 1 person.

node.text:
"We have a responsibility to draw the line and never accept that women can be destroyed in the way that is happening today."

The physician Denis Mukwege, awarded the 2018 Nobel Peace Prize, has spent large parts of his adult life helping victims of sexual violence in the Democratic Republic of Congo. Mukwege and his staff have treated thousands of patients who have been victims of such assaults. Most of the abuses have been committed in the context of a long-lasting civil war that has cost the lives of more than six million Congolese.

Mukwege is the foremost, most unifying symbol, both nationally and internationally, of the struggle to end sexual violence in war and armed conflicts. His basic principle is that “justice is everyone’s business”.

He has repeatedly condemned impunity for mass rape and criticised the Congolese government and other countries for not doing enough to stop the use of sexual violence against women as a strategy and weapon of war.

Photo: Alexander Mahmoud. 

#InternationalJusticeDay #justice #NobelPrize

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Nobel Prize on July 16, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says '"You can't build peace on empty stomachs." LORBOYR LORD BOYD ORR Nobel Peace Prize 1949'.

node.text:
The Scottish physician and biologist John Boyd Orr emerged in the inter-war years as one of Britain's leading experts on nutrition. He maintained that many Britons were malnourished because their incomes were too low. Boyd Orr participated in the efforts in the League of Nations to achieve an international policy on nutrition. During the Second World War, he proposed the idea of a "world food plan" to President Franklin D. Roosevelt of the USA. In 1945 he was elected Director-General of the FAO (Food and Agriculture Organization), the first of the specialised organisations established under the United Nations. Food and prosperity for all people on earth led to peace, Boyd Orr argued.

Boyd Orr was an ardent adherent of world organisation as a means of securing peace, and argued for a world government ruling according to rules of international law. The nations of the world were now so dependent on each other that they had to give up some of their sovereignty. Boyd Orr was elevated to the peerage for his national and international commitment.

In 1949 he was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize "for his lifelong effort to conquer hunger and want, thereby helping to remove a major cause of military conflict and war."

#NobelPrize #NobelLaureate #NobelPeacePrize #peace #quote

node.text:
What makes a successful scientist?

2020 Medicine Laureate Charles Rice shares his thoughts on what success means for a scientist.

Watch the full session at YouTube: https://youtu.be/ujQTD3wzzJs

#NobelPrize

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Nobel Prize on July 15, 2021. May be a black-and-white image of 3 people and people standing.

node.text:
Astrophysicist Subrahmanyan Chandrasekhar, known as ‘Chandra’, photographed on 19 October 1983, the day he was awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics for his work on the evolution of stars. 

Chandrasekhar adopted a highly unusual approach to his research, investigating a fresh field of study each decade, such as how stars die, how radiation passes through a star’s atmosphere and the theory of black holes. Each decade he followed a similar routine; writing a series of papers that solved the unsolved problems in that field, before finally publishing a book that summarised his results and presented the whole field in a new and clearer light. However, it is mainly for an early triumph, a theory developed while on a long sea voyage from India to the UK and that began his voyage through the stars, that Chandrasekhar was awarded the 1983 Nobel Prize in Physics. 

Photo: Bettmann / Getty Images

#NobelPrize #NobelLaureate

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Nobel Prize on July 14, 2021. May be an image of 6 people, people standing and indoor.

node.text:
Olga Tokarczuk: now and then.

As a child Literature Laureate Olga Tokarczuk was a voracious reader. Her father worked in a school library and she read pretty much everything she could get a hold of. Her first foray into writing was at the age of twelve, however instead of choosing to study literature at university, she chose psychology - a decision she says opened her eyes to the fact that one story can have many points of view.

She was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature 2018 for "for a narrative imagination that with encyclopedic passion represents the crossing of boundaries as a form of life."

Read Olga's biography by clicking the link in our bio.

Photos:
1) Olga Tokarczuk at the Nobel Prize award ceremony in 2019. Photo: Nanaka Adachi
2) Olga Tokarczuk photographed at the time of her graduation from the University of Warsaw in 1987. Photo: University of Warsaw.

#NobelPrize #NobelLaureate

node.text:
In the late 1800s Camillo Golgi developed a staining method that revealed the inner beauty of the nervous system. Working in a time before photographs could be taken from microscopes, he and his contemporaries would draw the intricate structures they studied in fine detail.

Golgi was awarded the Nobel Prize for Physiology and Medicine along with neuroscientist Santiago Ramón y Cajal, whose own drawings to him resembled a forest of outstretched trees.

Learn more about Golgi by clicking the link in our bio.

Image: by Camillo Golgi from Sulla fina anatomia degli organi centrali del sistema nervoso.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Nobel Prize on July 12, 2021 tagging @malala. May be a closeup of 1 person.

node.text:
The youngest Nobel Prize laureate ever, Malala Yousafzai, was only 17 years old at the time of the award. 

She was born on 12 July 1997 in Pakistan and was named after an Afghan poet, Malalai of Maiwand. Her father ensured that she received proper schooling and educated her at his private school. He added her name to the family register and she was allowed to stay up late and debate politics. From a young age Malala dreamt about becoming a doctor. 

Malala had a gift for public speaking and she began to speak up for girls’ rights to education. In 2009, Yousafzai started an anonymous blog for BBC Urdu. After her identity was revealed, the New York Times made a short film about her and her fight for education for all. 

As Yousafzai became more known, a death threat was issued against her. In 2012, Malala was shot three times by a masked gunman on a school bus. He threatened to kill all students on the school bus if she didn’t identify herself. The gunman also shot two of Malala’s friends. 

After intensive rehabilitation in the United Kingdom, she survived the gunshots. Fearlessly and with determination, Yousafzai kept fighting for girls’ right to education. Today, she is a role model for many young girls. 

In 2014, Malala Yousafzai received the Nobel Peace Prize for her bravery and work to ensure girls’ rights to education. 

Photo by Louise Kennerley/Fairfax Media via Getty Images

node.text:
"If unexpected things pop up, embrace them, rather than shy away from them. Because that's where the transformative discoveries are made."

2020 Medicine Laureate Charles Rice shares some important messages to all young students and researchers that have decided to dedicate their lives to science. 

Watch a full Q&A with Rice on YouTube - click the link in our bio to find it.

#NobelPrize #NobelLaureate #advice #students #science

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Nobel Prize on July 10, 2021. May be an image of 1 person.

node.text:
"The constant happiness is curiosity."

Happy 90th birthday to Alice Munro - the master of the contemporary short story.

Munro is renowned for her finely tuned storytelling, characterised by clarity and psychological realism. Her stories are often set in small town environments, where people's struggle for a decent life often result in difficult relationships and moral conflicts.

Learn more about her by clicking the link in our bio.

Photo: Sheila Munro, Copyright © The Nobel Foundation

#NobelPrize #NobelLaureate
